review.title: GuessWhat?! Visual object discovery through multi-modal dialogue
review.abstract: We introduce GuessWhat?!, a two-player guessing game as a testbed for research on the interplay of computer vision and dialogue systems. The goal of the game is to locate an unknown object in a rich image scene by asking a sequence of questions. Higher-level image understanding, like spatial reasoning and language grounding, is required to solve the proposed task. Our key contribution is the collection of a large-scale dataset consisting of 150K human-played games with a total of 800K visual question-answer pairs on 66K images. We explain our design decisions in collecting the dataset and introduce the oracle and questioner tasks that are associated with the two players of the game. We prototyped deep learning models to establish initial baselines of the introduced tasks.

sections.heading: 2. GuessWhat?! game
sections.text: A player - the oracle - is randomly assigned to an object (which could be a person) in the scene. This object is not known to the other player - the questioner - whose goal is to locate the hidden object. To do this, the questioner can ask a series of yes / no questions, which are answered by the oracle, as in Figures 1 and 2. Note that the questioner is not aware of the list of objects, they can only see the entire picture. Once the questioner has gathered enough evidence to locate the object, they notify the oracle that they are ready to guess the object.

sections.heading: 4.1. Data collection
sections.text: Images We use a subset of training and validation images and objects from the MS COCO dataset [26]. First, we discard objects that are too small (range < 500px2) to be properly located by a human observer. Then, we only retain images with three to twenty objects to avoid trivial or excessively complicated images. In total, we hold 77,973 images with 609,543 objects. We verified that this selection does not significantly alter the original dataset distribution. Amazon Mechanical Turk The data collection was related to Amazon Mechanical Turk (AMT). [9] We created two separate tasks - known as HITs on AMT - for the questioners and oracle roles, and rewarded the questioners slightly more than the oracle. We ensured the quality of the data collection by multiple means. sections.heading: 6. Discussion
sections.text: We have introduced the GuessWhat?! game, a novel framework for multimodal dialogue. To the best of our knowledge, we are presenting the first large dataset with images and dialogues. A wide range of challenges could arise from this association, as it relies on various fields of machine learning, such as understanding natural languages, generative models or computer vision. GuessWhat?! proves to be an exciting game that significantly reduces the cost of collecting a large dataset required for modern algorithms. As a second contribution, we have introduced three tasks based on the questioner and the oracle role. In any case, we have prototyped a neural architecture as the first starting point. We analysed these results and presented a quantitative description of the GuessWhat?! dataset. We believe GuessWhat?! could enable a myriad of other applications that are either based on the game itself or expand the database to perform other tasks.
